Comment: Unusual!  The sort of move played by my young grandson but I didn't let that put me off.  There are lots of sensible follow-ups...
Unusual!  The sort of move played by my young grandson but I didn't let that put me off.  There are lots of sensible follow-ups...
Black's moves conspire to hem my lsb in before it's even peeped out of the vestry.
Black's moves conspire to hem my lsb in before it's even peeped out of the vestry.
Black's moves conspire to hem my lsb in before it's even peeped out of the vestry.
Black's moves conspire to hem my lsb in before it's even peeped out of the vestry.

I reasoned that my Nb1 would probably get harassed if it moved to c3, so I planned moving it to d2 but didn't want to hem in my dsb.  This B has nothing much to bite on yet as the attack on the Q is easily foiled but would pin a N blocking the attack on the Q and could swap with a B doing the same.  If Black blocked with ...f6, that would weaken his kingside.  If Black left the B alone, it would be nicely placed.

Black unpins his N at the cost of depriving his Nb8 of its safest square.
Memories of my first game of the season (my last annotation) persuaded me against castling long.
This seemed an intemperate response with his K still stuck in the centre.  I think he was looking to trap my dsb.
! The battery on the e-file dominates the game for the next 10 moves.
! The battery on the e-file dominates the game for the next 10 moves.
! The battery on the e-file dominates the game for the next 10 moves.
I didn't have much choice here but saw it as an opportunity to develop an attack on his K

Black prepares to castle long but ...

Black prepares to castle long but ...
!  This N virtually seals Black's fate as he cannot castle now without budging it, which is very difficult...
I hadn't expected that but it wasn't very frightening.  I saw another opportunity to open a file for a rook.
Black has just played 3 consecutive moves to swap this N off and open a file for my other rook.
Black has just played 3 consecutive moves to swap this N off and open a file for my other rook.
I wasn't worried about doubling my extra pawns in view of the advantages that outweighed this minor (in this position) disadvantage .
This prevents ...Qc6, attacking g2 through my Nf3, and attacks c7, virtually forcing Black's reply.
This prevents ...Qc6, attacking g2 through my Nf3, and attacks c7, virtually forcing Black's reply.
Thanks to the previous move, this N can safely join the attack.
Thanks to the previous move, this N can safely join the attack.
It may seem odd to swap off this dominant N for a B that hasn't moved but I needed to operate on the Black squares to make progress and I had another N ready to land on e6.
It may seem odd to swap off this dominant N for a B that hasn't moved but I needed to operate on the Black squares to make progress and I had another N ready to land on e6.
Only after I played this did I spot that Black could try 20. .. Rfg8!?, attacking g2 while leaving the other rook to dominate the h-file, which I was hoping eventually to use for my Q.
Only after I played this did I spot that Black could try 20. .. Rfg8!?, attacking g2 while leaving the other rook to dominate the h-file, which I was hoping eventually to use for my Q.
Inwardly I breathed a sigh of relief to know that I didn't have to worry seriously about defence after all.

! I loved this move and for the first time my opponent really sank into thought.  Up to now, I had used about 10 minutes more than him.  Over the next few moves I developed a handy cushion.  What I loved about it was that it was a logical progression from my previous play while being far from obvious and, at first sight, like so many small Q moves, seemingly innocuous.  The more I looked into it, the better it seemed - a sort of puzzle reset move.
